I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The mandate for overall economic leadership in the Royal Government of Cambodia 
rests with the Prime Minister. To provide the Prime Minister with a dedicated resource for 
socioeconomic strategy and policy development and advice, the Supreme National Economic 
Council (SNEC) was created by Sub-decree in January 1999.1  According to its mandate, “the 
SNEC is the highest-level body mandated to provide the Prime Minister with technical analysis, 
advice, and recommendations with regard to policy and strategy for the rapid yet sustainable 
socioeconomic development of Cambodia”. Following the successful implementation of ADB 
technical assistance (TA) for institutional support to SNEC,2 the Government requested ADB for 
further TA to strengthen the institutional capacity of SNEC for national policy analysis and 
development management.3  A fact-finding mission in October 2004 and a follow-up mission in 
March 2005 reached understanding with the Government on the impact, outcome, outputs, 
implementation arrangements, cost, financial arrangements, and consulting services for the TA.  
A design and monitoring framework is provided in Appendix 1.   
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Cambodia is at a crossroads in its development as it moves away from a post-conflict 
situation towards a more normal development paradigm. More than two decades of international 
isolation and conflict that ended in 1991, with the signing of the Paris Peace Agreements, 
devastated much of the Country’s physical, social, and human capital, forcing Cambodia to start 
from scratch in rebuilding its infrastructure and institutions. Although important economic and 
social gains have been made over the past decade, the development agenda remains daunting. 
Poverty remains widespread and intense―with 35%–40% of the population remaining below 
the poverty line―and inequality appears to be increasing. Recent relatively robust growth has 
not led to a significant reduction in poverty, and achieving many of Cambodia’s Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs) will be difficult. 
 
3.  With peace and macroeconomic stability now more firmly entrenched, the country has 
the opportunity to make far-reaching reforms to achieve sustained socioeconomic development.  
However, this can only take place if key strategies, policies, and legislation are effectively 
formulated,  coordinated,  and  implemented.  Limited  Government  capacity  to  manage  this 
process constrains the speed and sustainability of the reform program. The limitations in policy 
analysis, coordination, and implementation are particularly evident in economic management. 
 
4.  Although key economic ministers provide advice and inputs on socioeconomic strategy 
and policy to the Prime Minister, their capacity to provide this on a sustained basis is limited, as 
they simultaneously attend to their respective ministries and departments and engage in a 
broad  array  of  interministerial,  sectoral,  regional,  and  international  responsibilities.  The 
establishment of SNEC is, therefore, an important initiative for strengthening domestic policy 
formulation and monitoring at the national level.  By being able to stand back from day-to-day 
work and the political pressures of regular Government ministries, SNEC can take a more 
independent  view  and  provide  the  Prime  Minister  with  more  rigorous,  objective  advice  on 
socioeconomic development issues.   
                                                 
1  As currently constituted, the SNEC is composed of a chairperson, five senior economic advisors (members), a 
secretary general, and technical staff. The chairperson has been given the rank of minister and the secretary 
general, the rank of secretary of state.  The secretary general heads the SNEC Secretariat. 
2 ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance to Cambodia for Institutional Support for National Economic Policy Management. 
Manila (TA 3721-CAM).  The technical assistance completion report was completed on 19 November 2004. 
3  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet edition) on 24 August 2004.

2   
 
5.  TA 3721-CAM: Institutional Support for National Economic Policy Management was 
designed to strengthen the capacity of the Government, particularly SNEC, in policy analysis 
and development management. The objectives of the TA were to (i) enable SNEC to perform its 
role in a responsive, professional, and timely manner; and (ii) provide training to the technical 
staff of the SNEC Secretariat. The TA was highly successful in providing wide-ranging outputs 
to the Prime Minister on a needs basis. The training of staff by means of 24 policy analysis 
clinics  was  also  considered  relevant.  The  TA  also  prepared  SNEC  2010,  the  Institutional 
Development Plan (IDP) of SNEC, to establish an institution able to serve on a continuous and 
sustainable basis and fulfill its mandate. However, the need to respond quickly and flexibly to 
events meant that the work agenda was to some extent driven by short-term objectives and 
there  was  insufficient  focus  on  the  need  for  longer-term  policy  analysis,  formulation,  and 
monitoring of development impacts. Such capability is even more necessary now, given the 
urgent need to implement the development vision set out in the Government’s Rectangular 
Strategy, by preparing a single planning document, the National Strategic Development Plan 
(NSDP) 2006–2010, which will follow the existing Second Socio-Economic Development Plan 
2001–2005 and the National Poverty Reduction Strategy 2003–2005.4 
 
6.  The Government sees the strengthening of SNEC as a matter of high priority and is 
committed to its future role. Given the level of support it enjoys within Government, SNEC has 
an important catalytic role to play in refining, implementing, and monitoring the reform program.  
Further development of SNEC’s institutional capacity will strengthen the Government’s ability to 
coordinate policy inputs, formulate appropriate policies, make rational choices among identified 
policy options, and monitor their implementation more effectively. 
 
7.  TA 3721 was a cost-effective and strategic intervention that has made a start in building 
capacity in SNEC for policy analysis and advice. The gains made will form the basis for further 
technical assistance to strengthen the capacity for policy analysis, formulation, and advice, and 
monitoring of development impacts. Based on lessons learned from TA 3721, and the need to 
ensure sustainable outcomes, future ADB assistance will focus on achieving a more clearly 
defined set of outputs consistent with the programs and activities in IDP. Towards this end, the 
training to be provided will build on and complement that already provided under TA 3721 to 
better equip the technical staff of SNEC with the means to solve problems and undertake the 
substantive  analytical  work  required  to  achieve  the  outputs  identified  in  this  TA.  The 
international consultant will consequently play more of an advisory and supervisory and / or 
mentoring role during this TA. To facilitate access to information and data and to help staff work 
on an ongoing and sustainable basis, the TA will also assist in developing a resource center for 
SNEC by providing computers and other IT-related equipment. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA aims to improve the quality, speed, and sustainability of the economic reform 
process in Cambodia by helping to improve Government capacity to coordinate, formulate, and 
monitor the implementation of national economic policies.  Towards this end, the TA will further 
strengthen the capacity of SNEC for national policy analysis and development management.  
                                                 
4  The Rectangular Strategy for Growth, Employment, Equity and Efficiency was prepared by the SNEC in 2004 and 
is intended to guide implementation of the Government’s economic agenda during its current mandate.  Although it 
sets out a lucid and coherent vision for development, it lacks an action plan and needs prioritization, costing, and 
linkage to the national budget and Medium-Term Expenditure Framework.

3
The major outputs expected of the TA are: (i) policy briefs, periodic economic assessments, and 
more  detailed  analytical  reports  on  topics  of  relevance  to  the  Prime  Minister;  (ii)  periodic 
revisions to the Medium Term Expenditure Framework (MTEF) to make it more comprehensive; 
(iii) inputs to the preparation of the Government’s new five-year planning document, the National 
Strategic Development Plan (NSDP) 2006–2010, to ensure consistency with other government 
policies and reforms, and to ensure that prioritized action plans in the NSDP are costed and 
linked to the budget and MTEF; (iv) annual NSDP progress reports; (v) in-depth policy research 
reports, and a half-yearly economic report for public dissemination;5 and (vi) better-trained 
technical  staff  of  SNEC,  capable  of  problem  solving  and  undertaking  analysis  in 
macroeconomics, and in the areas of responsibility of the members of SNEC (e.g., international 
development  finance,  agricultural  development,  infrastructure,  decentralization  and 
deconcentration, international trade, fiscal management, and international relations). 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  All the outputs are designed to directly or indirectly increase the capacity of SNEC for 
national policy analysis and development management. Crucial to strengthening the institutional 
capacity of SNEC for policy analysis and advice is the availability of a core staff with the 
requisite  skills  and  competencies.  By  orienting  the  training  towards  problem  solving  and 
producing high-quality outputs, SNEC will be in a better position to perform its role in a more 
responsive, professional, and timely manner. By developing the capacity of the staff to produce 
regular  and  high-quality  policy  briefs,  periodic  economic  assessments,  and  more  detailed 
analytical reports, SNEC will be better positioned to provide the Prime Minister with timely 
analysis and advice on policy issues, policy alternatives, and developments in the Cambodian 
and global economy. Developing a more comprehensive MTEF driven by transparent policy-
related fiscal parameters is integral to Cambodia’s development efforts, and key to effective and 
efficient use of resources to attain the desired growth and poverty reduction targets of the 
NSDP.  The  annual  progress  reports  of  the  NSDP  are  essential  to  monitor  progress  in 
implementing the reforms and achieving NSDP targets, and in providing feedback to planners 
and  policy makers  to make  necessary  mid  course  corrections.  Given  the  dearth  of  public 
information and discussion on socioeconomic issues relating to Cambodia’s development, the 
publication of the research outputs of SNEC and the periodic assessments of the Cambodian 
economy is aimed at promoting greater awareness and public participation in the development 
process.   
 
10.  The key activities of the TA to achieve the outputs are:  
 
(i)  upgrading the expertise of the technical staff of SNEC by providing on-the-job 
training with an emphasis on problem solving and providing refresher courses 
(on a need basis) in macroeconomics and the areas of responsibility of SNEC 
members; 
 
(ii)   helping develop a resource center for SNEC to enhance access to information 
and  data  by  providing  computers  and  other  IT-related  equipment  to  enable 
networking; 
 
(iii)  undertaking research and other analytical studies; 
                                                 
5  The policy research agenda will be developed by the international economic policy advisor in close collaboration 
with the secretary general of SNEC, and SNEC members.  It is envisaged that two to three such reports will be 
produced each year.

4   
 
(iv)  arranging  national  and  international  workshops  and  seminars  on  topics  of 
socioeconomic  relevance  to  Cambodia  and  SNEC,  including  discussion  of 
preliminary findings of SNEC’s research to encourage stakeholder participation in 
the  development  process  and  facilitate  exposure  to  best  practices  and 
knowledge; and 
 
(v)  disseminating  the  research  findings  and  periodic  economic  assessments  of  
SNEC through the publication of reports, where deemed appropriate. 
 
11.  The TA is based on the assumption that the Prime Minister will continue to involve 
SNEC in all relevant policy issues and ensure that it has access to necessary information. It 
also assumes that the Government will use the policy and economic analysis from SNEC and 
the progress reports on NSDP implementation to formulate policy and make needed revisions 
and/or mid course corrections to its reform program. There is also the implicit assumption that 
the topics covered in SNEC publications are of general interest and relevance. Against this, 
there is a risk that other organizations involved in policy formulation and implementation do not 
extend full cooperation to SNEC, thus hindering its effectiveness. There is also risk of a loss 
and/or redeployment of trained officers from SNEC, weakening its capacity to fulfill its mandate. 
Finally, the publications of SNEC may fail to attract much public interest due to lack of relevance 
of the topics covered and poor quality analysis. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $625,000 equivalent, comprising a foreign 
exchange cost of $254,000 and a local currency cost of $371,000 equivalent.  ADB will finance 
$500,000 equivalent covering the entire foreign exchange cost and $246,000 equivalent of the 
local currency cost.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program.  
The Government will finance $125,000 equivalent for office accommodation and transport, 
remuneration,  and  per  diem  of  counterpart  staff,  and  other  items  such  as  utilities,  local 
communications,  and  conference  and  workshop  venues.    A  schedule  of  the  detailed  cost 
estimates and financing plan is in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The TA will support  (i) one economic policy adviser (international consultant) providing 6 
person-months of services, performed intermittently in six visits over 24 months, and up to 80 
person-months  of  domestic  consulting  services,  including  those  of  an  IT  specialist,  on  an 
intermittent  basis.  It  is  envisaged  that  two  long-term  consultants,  both  macroeconomics 
specialists, will be recruited for 20 person-months each. The short-term consultants, who are 
expected to be sector specialists, will be recruited on a need basis. 
 
14.  The terms of reference (TOR) for the consulting services required are presented in 
Appendix 3. The international consultant and domestic consultants will be recruited on an 
individual basis, the latter from among Cambodian nationals. All consultants will be recruited in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants.   
 
15.  The Executing Agency for the TA will be SNEC, with its chairperson serving as the 
principal  coordinator.  SNEC  will  provide  office  space  for  the  international  and  domestic

5
consultants, including basic furnishings and support staff. The SNEC secretary general will act 
as the full-time counterpart staff of the international consultant.  
 
16.  The economic policy adviser (international consultant) will submit to ADB an inception 
report 1 month after the start of field services; half-yearly progress reports, a midterm report 
after 12 months of implementation; a draft final, and final report at the conclusion of the TA.  The 
inception report will include (i) a detailed work plan for the international consultant and expected 
outputs; (ii) detailed TORs for the two long-term domestic consultants, and the short-term 
consultants needed during the first year; and (iii) agreed upon indicators to monitor progress in 
achieving  the  expected  TA  outputs.  The  domestic  IT  specialist  will  be  responsible  for  the 
procurement of computers, a server, network components and related accessories, internet 
facilities,  and  customized  software  to  enable  SNEC  staff  to  fulfill  their  work  program  (all 
according to ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement). 
 
17.  The TA is expected to be implemented over 2 years, beginning June 2005 and closing 
May 2007.   
 
IV.   THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Cambodia for Capacity Building for National Economic Policy Analysis and 
Development Management, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Economic Policy Adviser (international, 6 person-months) 
 
1.  The economic policy adviser (policy adviser and/or adviser) shall serve a total of 6 
person-months in up to six missions over 24 months. 
 
2.  The policy adviser will have an advanced degree in economics, social sciences, 
political science, or a related field. He/she will have extensive experience (at least 10–15 
years) in policy processes, analysis and advice, and public sector management in several 
developing countries.  Experience in working with development issues and policies of the 
Greater Mekong countries will be an advantage.  He/she will have teaching experience and 
will be at ease conferring with senior government officials over sensitive issues; possess 
excellent communication and interpersonal skills; and be aware that the position will give 
access to material whose confidentiality must be respected at all times.  
 
3.  The policy adviser will provide on-the-job training to the technical staff of the SNEC 
secretariat  and,  in  close  collaboration  with  the  secretary  general,  refresher  courses  in 
macroeconomics on a need basis. 
 
4.  In close consultation with the secretary general and members of SNEC, the policy 
adviser will develop an overall policy research program for SNEC. The adviser will also 
provide  guidance  to  the  technical  staff  of  SNEC  in  undertaking  analytical  work,  and 
supervise the preparation of the policy research and economic analysis reports that will be 
published by SNEC. 
 
5.  More specifically, under the overall guidance of the chairperson of SNEC, and in 
close  collaboration  with  the  SNEC  secretary  general  (and  SNEC  members,  where 
appropriate), the policy adviser will undertake the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Training. The consultant’s tasks will include 
(a)  On-the-job training with an emphasis on problem solving and, on a 
need  basis,  design  and  implement  refresher  courses  in 
macroeconomics in areas relevant to the work of the technical staff of 
SNEC; and 
(b)  Provide staff with assignments on the basis of which their progress 
can be monitored. 
 
(ii)  Supervision and Guidance. The consultant will  
(a)  assist in developing the policy research program of SNEC and provide 
guidance for the analytical work and research studies assigned to 
individual technical staff; 
(b)  provide backstopping support to the technical staff whenever required; 
(c)  give regular feedback to the chairperson and secretary general on 
progress  of  research,  on  necessary  adjustments  in  the  research 
programs, and identify possible new areas of research; 
(d)  supervise  the  preparation  of  the  policy  research  and  economic 
analysis reports that will be published by SNEC; 
(e)  help the staff of SNEC to organize seminars and workshops on topics 
of  socioeconomic  relevance  to  Cambodia  and  SNEC  (including 
discussions of findings of research undertaken by SNEC’s technical 
staff);  help select  international  facilitators  for such  workshops  and 
seminars (if required); and 
(f)  provide guidance to technical staff/local consultants on survey design 
(if surveys are to be undertaken).

(e)  assist SNEC in ensuring that prioritized action plans in the NSDP are

B.   Domestic Consultants 
 
6.  A total of 80 person-months of services, to be discharged over 24 months, will be 
engaged under the TA. Of this, two long-term domestic consultants, both macroeconomics 
specialists, will be recruited for 20 months each.  One specialist will focus on fiscal policy 
issues, updating and further developing the MTEF, and ensuring that the prioritized action 
plans in the NSDP are costed and linked to the annual budget and MTEF. The other 
specialist  will  focus  on  overall  macroeconomic  management  and  forecasting  of 
macroeconomic  aggregates,  growth  and  investment  policy,  and  national  accounts.  The 
short-term consultants will be recruited on a need basis.1 The domestic consultants shall 
assist the chairperson, secretary general, and members of SNEC in performing their duties 
in support of the overall economic management mandate of the Prime Minister. 
 
1.  Reporting, Supervision and Performance Monitoring 
7.  Overall  guidance  for  the  domestic  consultants  will  be  provided  by  the  SNEC 
chairperson.  The  long-term  and  short-term  domestic  consultants  will  work  under  the 
operational direction of the SNEC secretary general. Depending on their specific thematic 
assignments, the short-term consultants will be assigned to a specific SNEC member. The 
domestic consultants shall report on their activities in advance of the reviews scheduled of 
their performance. 
8.  The secretary general shall certify the performance of the domestic consultants in 
collaboration with the economic policy adviser and, in the case of the short-term consultants, 
the  specific  SNEC  Member  directing  their  activities.  The  performance  of  the  domestic 
consultants will be evaluated against the achievement of clearly identifiable outputs, which 
are  specified  in  his/her  TOR  and  expected  to  be  achieved  during  the  period  of  the 
consultancy.  The  performance  of  the  long-term  domestic  consultants  will  be  formally

2.  Tasks 
9.  Given the parameters provided above, the domestic consultants shall 
(i)  undertake analysis of economic developments, policy issues, and research 
assigned to them by SNEC; 
(ii)  prepare memoranda, reports, and papers on the results of their analysis; 
(iii)  in coordination with the economic policy adviser, participate in training; 
(iv)  undertake surveys (if needed); and 
(v)  organize seminars and workshops to discuss macroeconomic and sectoral 
issues and the results of their analysis and research, as required by SNEC.
